title: 104_hr851
content:
The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" is established to create a project for rural telemedicine. The "Rural Telemedicine Act of 1995" establishes up to 10 pilot projects to investigate the use of rural health care provider telemedicine networks for physician consultative services under Medicare in rural areas. A rural health care provider telemedicine network is defined as a network of providers meeting specific requirements. A "provider telemedicine network" is a network of providers in rural areas that serve physicians, clinics, and nontertiary care providers. The network operates in rural areas and includes agreements for patient referral, joint communications systems, and transportation among members. The provider telemedicine network operates in rural areas, providing emergency and nonemergency transportation among members in designated rural or underserved areas. SEC. 3. MEDICARE PAYMENT FOR PARTICIPANTS. Under this Act, the Secretary will make payments from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for physicians' services in rural areas, even if the provider is not physically present. The methodology for determining payment amounts will be based on professional consultations with medicare beneficiaries. The Secretary will establish a methodology for determining payments for physician consultative services in rural areas, including payment for signal transmission facilities. Payments may also be made for services provided by nonphysician providers. Payments may be made for nonphysician providers for any service described in the paragraph, regardless of the provider being a physician or not. SEC. 4. ELIGIBILITY OF NETWORKS. Networks eligible for the pilot project must submit an application with required information and agree to provide necessary data to the Secretary. The term "rural area" is defined in the Act. The term "rural area" is defined in the Act as per section 1886(d)(2)(D) of the Social Security Act. SEC. 5. CRITERIA FOR SELECTING PARTICIPANTS.

Priority given to networks facilitating consultations between patients and specialists through detailed data transmission. Existing networks can participate in pilot projects.

SEC. 6. REPORTS. The Secretary must submit an interim report to Congress within 24 months of making payments for services under a pilot project, detailing the projects and networks involved, expenses, and number of patients served. A final report must be submitted within 1 year after project termination, including an analysis of cost-effectiveness and success in provider access promotion. The Secretary must submit reports to Congress detailing the cost-effectiveness and success of pilot projects in promoting provider access and patient care quality. Recommendations for changes in the medicare program related to telemedicine should also be included, along with cost estimates. Authorization of appropriations from the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund for a total of $51,000,000 for a demonstration project under this Act, with up to $1,000,000 allocated for administrative purposes, including report preparation.
